content.text: Classical logic assumes every proposition is either true or false — exactly two values. **Many-valued logics** allow three or more truth values, opening new possibilities for handling uncertainty, vagueness, and future contingents.

content.definition: A logical system with more than two truth values. Common systems have three values (true, false, indeterminate) or infinitely many values (degrees from 0 to 1).

content.text: **Jan Łukasiewicz** developed three-valued logic in 1920 to handle future contingents: is 'There will be a sea battle tomorrow' true or false today? He added a third value: indeterminate.

content.title: Three-Valued Truth Table for ¬
content.note: Negating something indeterminate doesn't make it determinate.

content.text: **Fuzzy logic**, developed by Lotfi Zadeh, uses infinitely many values from 0 to 1. 'Tall' isn't simply true or false — someone 5'10" might be 'tall to degree 0.7.' This models vagueness in natural language.

content.definition: A many-valued logic using truth values from 0 to 1 (continuous degrees). Used in AI, control systems, and modeling vague predicates like 'tall,' 'warm,' or 'fast.'

content.question: Why did Łukasiewicz introduce a third truth value?
content.explanation: Łukasiewicz introduced a third value (indeterminate) to handle statements about the future that are neither definitely true nor definitely false yet, like 'There will be a sea battle tomorrow.'
